moves.1. d4: An interesting middle game, with a too-risky sac, that put me in a bad position. I won because a piece was returned from my opponent... I think it was not necessary, but it is still to prove he coud have avoided to return the piece.
moves.1... Nf6 2. Nf3 g6 3. Bf4 Bg7 4. c3 O-O: A risky move, but still not "the" sacrifice. This is just to open the attack line.
moves.9... h5 10. Ng5 e5 11. Bxg4 exf4 12. Bxh: Maybe Nd2-f3 could have been better. Or Qg4, just supporting the next sac,  Bxg6...
moves.14. Nxf7 Qh4+ 15. Rg3 Rxf7 16. Bxg6 Rg7: If he plays d6-d5, he loses his strong bishop's action, but I can resign, since I have no compensation anymore.
moves.21. e4 Bxe4: I saw the checkmate black has now. I must take the bishop, or QxN and Rg1 mate.
moves.23... Nxd2: I can recover with QxB+, but there is no win in it.
moves.24. Rg3 Qe7: Is he returning the piece because he had no choice, or thought it, or it was just a blunder?
moves.25. Qxh6+ Rh7 26. Qxd2: Plus one. Does this prove the knight sac was right? I don't think so...
moves.26... Re8 27. Qg2 Qe6 28. Qf2 Rf7: I hate finals, but I couldn't see a clear win with checks. Maybe I was wrong, I had to go for checks with Qg1...
moves.29. Rf3: The rest is simple finals technique... something I am very bad at.
